Question: Android InputStream.read() horribly slow:I'm working on an Android app that needs to communicate with a server (running on my PC) which is also written by me. The problem is that InputStream.read() takes an eternity, processing 200kb takes something around 30 seconds. My code: client = new Socket("192.168.1.1", 1235);
client.setTcpNoDelay(true);
client.setReceiveBufferSize(1048576);
InputStream is = client.getInputStream();

byte[] buffer = new byte[1048576];
int i = 0;
int length = -1;

while (true)
{
    int b = is.read();
    if (b == -1)
    {
        success = false;
        break;
    }
    buffer[i] = (byte) b;

    if (i == length)
        break;

                                    if (i == 3)
                                    {
                                                length = buffer[0] | buffer[1] << 8 | buffer[2] << 16 | buffer[3] << 24;
                                                    
                                        }

                                        i++;

        }
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer:<<<api>>>: InputStream.read
<<<code>>>: final byte[] lengthBuffer = new byte[3];
try{
    int b = is.read(lengthBuffer);
    // make sure b was 3 and do your length calculation
    final byte buffer = new byte[length];
    b = is.read(buffer);
    // check b and then you have your bytes}
except {System.out.println("Something went wrong.");")}
<<<explanation>>>: Why are you reading each byte individually? It looks like you really want to read the first 3 bytes and figure out your length and then read that block. Then you can at least get the optimizations that Inputstream can provide for reading blocks of data rather than one byte at a time. And you are not allocating that mega array like you currently have.
Question: Efficient way to search a stream for a string: :Let's suppose that have a stream of text (or Reader in Java) that I'd like to check for a particular string. The stream of text might be very large so as soon as the search string is found I'd like to return true and also try to avoid storing the entire input in memory.Naively, I might try to do something like this (in Java):public boolean streamContainsString(Reader reader, String searchString) throws IOException {    char[] buffer = new char[1024];    int numCharsRead;    while((numCharsRead = reader.read(buffer)) > 0) {        if ((new String(buffer, 0, numCharsRead)).indexOf(searchString) >= 0)            return true;    }    return false;}Of course this fails to detect the given search string if it occurs on the boundary of the 1k buffer:Search text: "stackoverflow"Stream buffer 1: "abc.........stack"Stream buffer 2: "overflow.......xyz"How can I modify this code so that it correctly finds the given search string across the boundary of the buffer but without loading the entire stream into memory?Edit: Note when searching a stream for a string, we're trying to minimise the number of reads from the stream (to avoid latency in a network/disk) and to keep memory usage constant regardless of the amount of data in the stream. Actual efficiency of the string matching algorithm is secondary but obviously, it would be nice to find a solution that used one of the more efficient of those algorithms.
Please using this api: InputStream.read.
Answer:<<<api>>>: InputStreamReader
<<<code>>>: 
```
public boolean streamContainsString(InputStream inputStream, String searchString) throws IOException {
    InputStreamReader reader = new InputStreamReader(inputStream);
    char[] buffer = new char[1024];
    int numCharsRead;
    while((numCharsRead = reader.read(buffer)) > 0) {
        if (new String(buffer, 0, numCharsRead).indexOf(searchString) >= 0)
            return true;
    }
    return false;
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: The InputStreamReader is a bridge from byte streams to character streams. It uses a default charset to convert bytes to characters. It's more efficient than reading bytes directly and then converting them to characters. It also avoids the issue of not being able to detect the given search string if it occurs on the boundary of the buffer.

Question: How to read large files in chunks in Android: :I'm trying to read a large file (like 1GB) in chunks in Android. I've tried using a BufferedInputStream and read the file in chunks, but it's not working as expected. The file is not being read in chunks. Here is my code:
```
try {
    File file = new File(filePath);
    FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(file);
    BufferedInputStream bis = new BufferedInputStream(fis);
    byte[] buffer = new byte[8192];
    int bytesRead;
    while ((bytesRead = bis.read(buffer)) != -1) {
        // Do something with the data
    }
    bis.close();
} catch (IOException e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}
```
What am I doing wrong?
Please using this api: BufferedInputStream.read.
Answer:<<<api>>>: BufferedInputStream.read
<<<code>>>: 
```
try {
    File file = new File(filePath);
    FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(file);
    BufferedInputStream bis = new BufferedInputStream(fis);
    byte[] buffer = new byte[8192];
    int bytesRead;
    while ((bytesRead = bis.read(buffer, 0, buffer.length)) != -1) {
        // Do something with the data
    }
    bis.close();
} catch (IOException e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
}
```
<<<explanation>>>: The problem with your code is that you are not specifying the length of the buffer that you are reading into. The read(byte[] b, int off, int len) method of BufferedInputStream reads up to len bytes into the array b starting at the index off. By specifying the length of the buffer, you ensure that the read method reads exactly that many bytes and you avoid any possible buffer overflow.
